results.headline: Friends and Family
results.summary_short: “A Thousand Years of Good Prayers” is a gentle, pleasantly unrushed piece of moviemaking.

results.headline: Dreaming of Elvis, Living a Nightmare
results.summary_short: This overripe tale of innocence lost has become one of notoriety found.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hounddog

results.headline: Three Disparate (and Desperate) Women
results.summary_short: “Fräulein” presents immigrant lives with significantly more empathy than detail.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fraulein

results.headline: Relationships Beyond Borders
results.summary_short: Realistic performances make Matthew Bonifacio’s quiet charmer “Amexicano” much more than just another preachy treatise on illegal immigration.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amexicano

results.headline: Lurking in the Shadows of Suburbia, a Menacing Neighbor With a Gun
results.summary_short: Considered purely as a formal exercise, “Lakeview Terrace” is a passable piece of hackwork, with some adequately suspenseful passages.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lakeview Terrace

results.headline: A Frankenstein Tale With a Twist
results.summary_short: There’s scant reward for sitting through “Igor,” an animated twist on the Frankenstein story that never sparks to life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Igor

results.headline: At Home in a War Zone
results.summary_short: “Elite Squad” is a relentlessly ugly, unpleasant, often incoherent assault on the senses from Brazil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elite Squad

results.headline: Georgiana and Her Dull, Dallying Duke
results.summary_short: “The Duchess” is an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Duchess

results.headline: Gunman Meets Widow. Trouble Starts.
results.summary_short: “Appaloosa” shows a square jaw and a steely gaze, but also a smile and a wink.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Appaloosa

results.headline: A Fan and Advocate of Films Becomes the Subject of One
results.summary_short: This affectionate, insidery portrait of Pierre Rissient introduces one of the seminal, behind-the-scenes figures of contemporary movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pierre Rissient: Man of Cinema

results.headline: Money Isn’t Everything When Values Are at Stake
results.summary_short: “Tyler Perry’s The Family That Preys” is a sudsy, interracial fable about the power of greed to destroy families and erode morality.
results.display_title: Tyler Perry's The Family That Preys

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's The Family That Preys

results.headline: The War Between Public Health and Private Interests
results.summary_short: A documentary and a three-alarm warning, “Flow” dives into our planet’s most essential resource to find pollution, scarcity, human suffering and corporate profit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flow

results.headline: Small Eyes on the Big Stage
results.summary_short: It would take a superhuman capacity for cynicism to resist the radiant optimism of the Missoula Children’s Theater players and the unabashed pep of this joyful portrait.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Little Red Truck

results.headline: Packing Up the Plantation and Finding Distant, Unexpected Connections
results.summary_short: Godfrey Cheshire’s documentary “Moving Midway: A Southern Plantation in Transit” tells a fascinating and complicated story of regional identity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moving Midway

results.headline: Culture Wars Waged in Suburban Bedrooms
results.summary_short: In “Towelhead,” a provocative satire of a culture that is paradoxically hypersexual and puritanical, teenage sexuality makes everyone bonkers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Towelhead

results.headline: Sociocultural Commentary...and Singing!
results.summary_short: “Loins of Punjab Presents” is a witty musical comedy with a sharp political edge.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Loins of Punjab Presents

results.headline: Waves of Emotion
results.summary_short: “Greetings From the Shore” is a watchable-enough summer-at-the-beach tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greetings From the Shore

results.headline: Ghost Story and Group Therapy
results.summary_short: Jewish mental patients and murdered Palestinians unite to solve the problems of the Middle East in “Forgiveness.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forgiveness

results.headline: Catfights and Class Struggles, but Not at Katz’s Deli
results.summary_short: Watching “The Women,” you wait in vain for a moment of snappy repartee, of fresh emotion, of grace or charm or pathos. You wait, by the way, for a very long time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Women

results.headline: A History Lesson and a Call to Arms
results.summary_short: “Secrecy” prowls through the labyrinth of information suppression and, as might be expected in so murky a milieu, winds up a little lost.
